study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the feasibility and effectiveness of electronic behavioral interventions, including Relaxation Therapy, for primary headache disorders delivered outside clinical settings.
results_summary: Relaxation Therapy was used in 35% of the studies, showing acceptability to patients, but data on long-term efficacy, required dose, and health data security were limited. The majority of studies combined multiple behavioral modalities.
population_specificity: Patients with primary headache disorders.
study_duration: Ranged from 4 days to 60 months (specific to Relaxation Therapy not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of cognitive behavior psychophysiological therapy (CBPT) and music and relaxation therapy (MRT) in improving panic disorder severity and asthma control in Latino adults with comorbid asthma and panic disorder.
results_summary: Both CBPT and MRT showed improvements in panic disorder severity, asthma control, and other anxiety and asthma outcomes from baseline to post-treatment and 3-month follow-up. CBPT had an advantage over MRT in improving adherence to inhaled corticosteroids.
population_specificity: Primarily Puerto Rican Latino adults with asthma and panic disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of relaxation therapy and cognitive stress on central pain modulation in chronic WAD and FM patients compared to healthy individuals.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy decreased temporal summation (TS) of pain in chronic WAD patients and controls but increased TS in FM patients. Conditioned pain modulation (CPM) efficacy worsened in all groups after relaxation and cognitive stress.
population_specificity: Chronic whiplash associated disorders (WAD) patients (n=16), fibromyalgia (FM) patients (n=21), and pain-free controls (n=22).
effective_dosage: Not specified (single session of progressive relaxation therapy).
study_duration: Single session, with follow-up measurements one week later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of cognitive rehabilitation with relaxation therapy and treatment as usual for managing cognitive difficulties in Parkinson's disease dementia and dementia with Lewy bodies.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for relaxation therapy, as it describes a pilot study design without outcome data.
population_specificity: Participants with Parkinson's disease, Parkinson's disease dementia, or dementia with Lewy bodies, recruited from movement disorders, care for the elderly, and memory clinics.
effective_dosage: Eight weekly sessions (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of relaxation therapy as a complementary treatment for bladder pain syndrome in women.
results_summary: The study identified relaxation therapy as one of the interventions studied, but the abstract does not provide specific results for its efficacy. The conclusion highlights dietary management, acupuncture, and physical therapy as having potential benefit, suggesting relaxation therapy may not have shown significant effects.
population_specificity: Women with bladder pain syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of relaxation therapy as a nonpharmacologic treatment for insomnia, particularly its effectiveness in improving sleep quality and daytime functioning.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy is identified as one of the nonpharmacologic therapies effective for treating insomnia, alongside cognitive behavior therapy and sleep hygiene. It is associated with improved sleep outcomes, though the abstract does not provide specific efficacy data for relaxation therapy alone.
population_specificity: Individuals with insomnia, particularly women (post-menopause and late pregnancy) and older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of non-pharmacological interventions, including relaxation therapy, for people with epilepsy and intellectual disabilities.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding relaxation therapy, as the only included study compared surgical procedures.
population_specificity: People with epilepsy and intellectual disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acupuncture and relaxation therapy affect the autonomic nervous system response and pain inhibition in patients with chronic whiplash-associated disorders (WAD).
results_summary: The study found no differences between acupuncture and relaxation therapy in changing autonomic parameters. The reduction in pain sensitivity from acupuncture was unrelated to autonomic changes, suggesting relaxation therapy had comparable effects on autonomic response but no specific pain inhibition mechanism was identified.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic whiplash-associated disorders (WAD)
study_duration: Two treatment sessions (one per therapy type)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treating chronic PTSD with relaxation therapy (among other therapies) would affect the stability of personality disorder diagnoses.
results_summary: The study found that relaxation therapy, along with other treatments, led to a reduction in baseline personality disorder diagnoses post-treatment, but treatment modality and PTSD response were unrelated to PD improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Relaxation Therapy (RT) versus Motivational Interviewing (MI) in reducing delinquent behaviors and depressive symptoms among incarcerated adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that MI was more effective than RT in reducing predatory aggression and alcohol-related predatory aggression 3 months post-release, particularly when depressive symptoms were low. RT's efficacy was not highlighted as superior in any measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Incarcerated adolescents in a state correctional facility in the Northeast region.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of behavioral and psychological treatments, including relaxation therapy, on people with epilepsy.
results_summary: The study categorized the efficacy of relaxation therapy (alone or combined with behavioral modification therapy) based on systematic reviews and RCTs, suggesting it may have beneficial effects for people with epilepsy. However, specific details on the magnitude of these effects were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: People with epilepsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of balneotherapy (seated immersion) versus relaxation therapy and other treatments in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in pain or physical disability between balneotherapy and relaxation therapy, with very low-level evidence supporting this conclusion.
population_specificity: Patients with definitive or classical rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of muscular factors in tension-type headache (TTH) and assess non-pharmacological therapies, including relaxation therapy, for managing episodic TTH.
results_summary: The study suggests that relaxation therapy, alongside other non-pharmacological treatments like biofeedback and physiotherapy, may help manage TTH by addressing peripheral and central sensitization mechanisms. However, the abstract does not provide specific efficacy data for relaxation therapy alone.
population_specificity: Individuals with episodic tension-type headache (TTH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess patient preferences for PTSD psychotherapies, including Relaxation Therapy, and explore how these preferences influenced treatment outcomes.
results_summary: Relaxation Therapy was preferred by 26% of patients, but treatment preference did not significantly predict changes in PTSD symptoms. Comorbid depression appeared to worsen outcomes for patients receiving unwanted treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic DSM-IV PTSD (CAPS score ≥ 50) recruited between 2008 and 2013.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of balneotherapy (seated immersion) versus relaxation therapy in managing symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in pain or physical disability between balneotherapy and relaxation therapy, with very low levels of evidence supporting these findings.
population_specificity: Participants with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effect of self-administered foot reflexology in patients with chronic health conditions, including type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and urinary incontinence.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to conclusively determine the effectiveness of self-administered foot reflexology, though some positive effects were noted in type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and urinary incontinence, limited by low study quality and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic health conditions (type 2 diabetes, hypertension, urinary incontinence).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of relaxation therapy (as an active control) with interpersonal psychotherapy and prolonged exposure in treating chronic PTSD.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy showed a 38% response rate (improvement in CAPS score) and had large within-group effect sizes (d=1.32-1.88), but it was less effective than IPT and prolonged exposure in improving quality of life and social functioning.
population_specificity: 110 unmedicated patients with chronic PTSD (CAPS score >50), stratified for comorbid major depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cognitive-behavioral stress management (CBSM) delivered after surgery for early-stage breast cancer improved long-term depressive symptoms and quality of life compared to a control group.
results_summary: Participants who received CBSM reported significantly lower depressive symptoms and better quality of life up to 15 years later compared to the control group, with moderate effect sizes.
population_specificity: Women with stage 0 to IIIb breast cancer, recruited 2 to 10 weeks after surgery.
study_duration: 10 weeks (initial intervention), with follow-up assessments 8 to 15 years later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding Rajyoga meditation to routine medical treatment improves outcomes for chronic tension-type headache (CTTH) patients compared to medical treatment alone.
results_summary: Patients receiving meditation alongside medical treatment showed significantly greater relief in headache severity, duration, and frequency (94%, 91%, and 97% improvement, respectively) compared to those receiving only medical treatment (36%, 36%, and 49% improvement). The headache index improved by 99% in the meditation group versus 51% in the control group.
population_specificity: 50 patients aged 18-58 years with a clinical diagnosis of chronic tension-type headache.
effective_dosage: 8 lessons and practical demonstrations of Rajyoga meditation (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of guided imagery relaxation therapy on pain management and depression in fibromyalgia patients.
results_summary: The treatment group showed statistically significant reductions in pain and depression at week 4, but no significant differences were found for pain at week 8. Guided imagery was effective in alleviating symptoms, particularly in the short term.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with fibromyalgia, aged 18 to 70 years (n = 60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Benson's relaxation technique could relieve pain and improve quality of life in haemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that Benson's relaxation technique significantly reduced pain intensity and improved overall quality of life, including health-functioning, socioeconomic, and family subscales, compared to routine care.
population_specificity: Haemodialysis patients from two units affiliated with Shiraz University of Medical Sciences.
effective_dosage: Patients listened to an audiotape of the relaxation technique twice daily for 20 minutes each session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Benson's relaxation technique in improving sleep quality among hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in sleep quality, including reductions in sleep disturbance, daytime dysfunction, and use of sleep medication, as well as better subjective sleep quality and global PSQI scores in the intervention group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients in Iran.
effective_dosage: Twice daily for 20 minutes each session.

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of venlafaxine and transdiagnostic CBT, alone and in combination, on alcohol intake in individuals with co-morbid alcohol use and anxiety disorders, including Progressive Muscle Relaxation therapy (PMR) as a comparison.
results_summary: The study found that the PLC-CBT group had greater reductions in heavy drinking compared to the PLC-PMR group, but PMR alone did not show significant superiority over the comparison group. Only the PLC-CBT group demonstrated significantly decreased heavy drinking when contrasted to the comparison group.
population_specificity: Individuals with co-morbid alcohol use disorders (AUDs) and anxiety disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether relaxation therapy, as part of complex interventions, could reduce urgent healthcare utilization in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: Relaxation therapy was associated with a significant reduction in urgent healthcare use (OR = 0.48, 95% CI = 0.33, 0.70), indicating strong efficacy. The effect was more pronounced than general education or exercise alone.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of applied progressive muscle relaxation training (APMRT) on depression, anxiety, and stress levels in prostate cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in anxiety and stress levels among prostate cancer patients receiving APMRT, but no improvement in depression. The control group showed no such improvements.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer patients from two medical centers in Malaysia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of relaxation therapy (RT) versus motivational interviewing (MI) in reducing alcohol and marijuana use among incarcerated adolescents, with a focus on ethnic differences.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy was less effective than MI for Hispanic adolescents in reducing heavy drinking days and total drinks on heavy drinking days. No significant differences were reported for other ethnic groups.
population_specificity: Incarcerated adolescents (14-19 years old; 48 White, 51 Hispanic, 48 African American; 126 male, 21 female).
study_duration: Intervention duration not specified; follow-up was 3 months post-release.

study_goal: To determine the impact of applied progressive muscle relaxation training on health-related quality of life among prostate cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in mental component summary (MCS) and overall health-related quality of life in the intervention group compared to the comparison group, but no significant difference in physical component summary (PCS).
population_specificity: Prostate cancer patients from University Malaya Medical Centre and Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia Medical Centre.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether breathing exercises, including relaxation therapy, improved quality of life and symptom severity in patients with dysfunctional breathing/hyperventilation syndrome (DB/HVS).
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in hyperventilation attack frequency and severity in the breathing exercise group compared to the control group, but no data on quality of life or treatment effect size was available. The authors concluded that the evidence was insufficient to inform clinical practice due to the study's poor reporting and small sample size.
population_specificity: Adults with dysfunctional breathing/hyperventilation syndrome (DB/HVS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the prevalence of use of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM), including Relaxation Therapy, among physicians in the UK.
results_summary: Relaxation Therapy was identified as one of the three most commonly used CAM methods by physicians in the UK, but the study did not specifically evaluate its efficacy or outcomes. The abstract notes that many physicians using CAM lack formal training, raising concerns about professional competence.
population_specificity: Physicians in the UK

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various behavioral therapies, including Relaxation Therapy, for treating Tourette syndrome (TS).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Relaxation Therapy was among the treatments reviewed, but its efficacy remains unclear due to insufficient evidence, requiring further investigation. HRT was identified as the most effective, while other therapies, including Relaxation Therapy, lacked conclusive support.
population_specificity: Individuals with Tourette syndrome (TS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence and recommendations for psychological interventions, including Relaxation Therapy, in the rehabilitation of patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that Relaxation Therapy is part of multimodal, multidisciplinary rehabilitation programs for chronic low back pain, but the available evidence is of moderate to low quality, and specific problem-treatment pairs are not well-defined in most guidelines.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term efficacy of a multidisciplinary headache treatment program, including progressive muscle relaxation therapy, in reducing headache frequency and related disability.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in headache frequency (≥50% reduction in 62.7% of patients) and improvements in secondary outcomes like disability and anxiety/depression. Familiarity with progressive muscle relaxation therapy at baseline was a predictor for good outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with frequent difficult-to-treat headaches (n=201), including migraine, tension-type headache, combined migraine/tension-type headache, and medication overuse headache.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of relaxation therapy and acupuncture on endogenous analgesia activation and symptom relief in patients with chronic whiplash-associated disorders (WAD).
results_summary: Relaxation therapy showed no significant differences compared to acupuncture in conditioned pain modulation, temporal summation of pressure pain, neck disability, or symptom severity. Both treatments were well-tolerated, but acupuncture demonstrated greater acute improvements in local pressure pain sensitivity.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic whiplash-associated disorders (WAD) (n = 39).
effective_dosage: Not specified (two treatment sessions of identical duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if relaxation therapy, among other interventions, could effectively manage anxiety and depression in patients recovering from heart surgery.
results_summary: The study found that moderate to severe anxiety and depression during the first month of home recovery affect self-management behaviors in heart surgery patients. Relaxation therapy was presented as an evidence-based recommendation for managing these psychological conditions.
population_specificity: Patients who had coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) and/or valvular replacement surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of behavioral and psychological treatments, including relaxation therapy, for people with partial or generalized epilepsy.
results_summary: The study included relaxation therapy among behavioral and psychological treatments but did not provide specific results for relaxation therapy alone. The overall findings suggest some efficacy for these interventions in managing epilepsy.
population_specificity: People with partial or generalized epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary treatment program (MTP) for headache patients, including adherence to relaxation therapy and its impact on headache frequency reduction.
results_summary: The study found that 61% of patients adhered to relaxation therapy, which was associated with better treatment outcomes. Adherence to lifestyle modifications, including relaxation therapy, predicted a reduction in headache frequency.
population_specificity: 295 headache patients (210 migraine, 17 tension-type headache, 68 combination headache, including 56 medication-overuse headache).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of a nurse-led CBT program, including relaxation therapy, on fatigue and quality of life in breast cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: The nurse-led CBT program, which included relaxation therapy, resulted in a lower increase in fatigue levels compared to the control group and significantly improved quality of life in breast cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer undergoing radiotherapy at P University Hospital in Korea (N = 71).

study_goal: To determine the effect of music therapy and verbal relaxation on state anxiety and anxiety-induced physiological manifestations among patients with cancer before and after chemotherapy.
results_summary: Music therapy had a greater positive effect on postchemotherapy anxiety than verbal relaxation and control groups, with a significant increase in skin temperature. Patients with high state anxiety receiving music therapy had a greater drop in postchemotherapy anxiety than the normal state anxiety subsample. Both interventions were effective in reducing chemotherapy-induced anxiety, with 30 minutes of intervention initiating anxiety reduction.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer receiving chemotherapy at an outpatient clinic in southern Taiwan.
effective_dosage: Music therapy group received one-hour single music session; verbal relaxation group received 30 minutes of guided relaxation.
study_duration: Single session (one hour for music therapy, 30 minutes for verbal relaxation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationships between breathing pattern abnormalities and symptoms of dysfunctional breathing, as measured by the Nijmegen Questionnaire (NQ), and to assess the effects of relaxation therapy on these symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that relaxation therapy significantly improved both dysfunctional breathing symptoms (measured by NQ) and breathing patterns (measured by MARM), with the greatest improvements seen in patients with abnormal breathing patterns pre-treatment. Dyspnea symptoms correlated with abnormal breathing patterns and showed the largest reduction post-treatment.
population_specificity: 62 patients with medically unexplained complaints associated with tension and breathing dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of relaxation therapy as a nonpharmacologic intervention for managing acute pain after hip fracture.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to determine the benefits or harms of relaxation therapy in managing acute pain after hip fracture, as data on this intervention were sparse.
population_specificity: Older adults with acute hip fracture.

study_goal: The researchers examined the efficacy of relaxation therapy in reducing anxiety and depression in patients with COPD.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that relaxation therapy is among the treatments with evidence for efficacy in reducing anxiety and depression in COPD patients, though the quality and quantity of research are historically insufficient for inclusion in guidelines.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) experiencing psychological co-morbidities such as anxiety and depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the relative strengths of direct and indirect pathways (via mood) through which relaxation therapy might affect IBS symptoms.
results_summary: The study found indirect pathways via mood (primarily anxiety, to a lesser extent depression) linking relaxation therapy to changes in bowel symptoms, but no direct effect on symptoms.
population_specificity: 105 people with Rome I IBS (36 randomized to relaxation therapy).

study_goal: To assess the efficacy of relaxation therapy in reducing hot flushes in women with a history of breast cancer.
results_summary: One of two studies on relaxation therapy showed a significant benefit in reducing hot flushes, while the other did not. The therapy demonstrated a mild to moderate effect overall.
population_specificity: Women with a history of breast cancer experiencing hot flushes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of psychological interventions, including relaxation therapy, in improving dyspepsia symptoms and quality of life in patients with non-ulcer dyspepsia (NUD).
results_summary: The review found that psychological interventions, including relaxation therapy, may benefit dyspepsia symptoms, with effects persisting for one year, but the evidence was insufficient due to small sample sizes, low recruitment, and high dropout rates. Unadjusted data was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with non-ulcer dyspepsia (NUD).
study_duration: Effects were noted to persist for one year, but exact intervention duration was not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess predictors and treatment strategies for HIV-related fatigue, including the role of relaxation therapy among other interventions.
results_summary: The study found that HIV-related fatigue is strongly associated with psychological factors like depression and anxiety, and relaxation therapy was listed as one of the therapeutic interventions, though specific efficacy details were not provided.
population_specificity: HIV-infected individuals experiencing fatigue.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify sources and effects of stress in Singaporean nurses and evaluate coping strategies, including relaxation therapy.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy was reported as a common coping strategy among nurses to reduce the negative effects of work stressors, alongside problem orientation and social support. The abstract suggests relaxation therapy may help mitigate stress but does not provide detailed efficacy data.
population_specificity: Singaporean nurses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of cognitive rehabilitation (CR) with relaxation therapy and no treatment in early-stage Alzheimer disease (AD).
results_summary: Relaxation therapy did not produce significant improvements in goal performance and satisfaction, unlike cognitive rehabilitation. Scores in the relaxation therapy group remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 69 individuals (41 women, 28 men; mean age 77.78 years) with early-stage AD or mixed AD and vascular dementia, and 44 family carers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether behavioral neurocardiac training (BNT) with heart rate variability biofeedback outperforms autogenic relaxation (a form of relaxation therapy) in reducing blood pressure and improving vagal heart rate modulation in hypertensive patients.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy (autogenic relaxation) showed no significant effect on blood pressure or heart rate modulation, while BNT modestly reduced ambulatory blood pressure and improved vagal heart rate modulation. Neither intervention altered spontaneous baroreflex sensitivity.
population_specificity: 65 patients with uncomplicated hypertension
effective_dosage: Six 1-hour sessions over 2 months with home practice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of behavioral and psychological treatments, including relaxation therapy, for people with partial or generalized epilepsy.
results_summary: The study included relaxation therapy among behavioral and psychological treatments but did not provide specific results for relaxation therapy alone. The overall findings suggest these treatments may have some benefit, but detailed efficacy data for relaxation therapy specifically are not highlighted.
population_specificity: People with partial or generalized epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of psychological therapies, including Relaxation Therapy, on chronic pain reduction, disability, and emotional functioning in youth.
results_summary: Relaxation Therapy produced significant and positive effects on pain reduction in youth with headache, abdominal pain, and fibromyalgia, with large effect sizes at immediate post-treatment and follow-up. Effects on disability and emotional functioning were small and non-significant, though data on these outcomes were limited.
population_specificity: Youth (children and adolescents) with chronic pain conditions, including headache, abdominal pain, and fibromyalgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of different reminiscence therapy delivery formats on cognitive function, depressive symptoms, quality of life, and adherence in people with dementia or mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: Digital reminiscence therapy was most effective for improving cognitive function and reducing depressive symptoms, while individual reminiscence therapy ranked highest for quality of life. Group reminiscence therapy showed the best adherence rates.
population_specificity: Older adults with dementia or mild cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of reminiscence therapy in improving well-being and quality of life among elderly residents in an old age home.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements, with well-being scores increasing by 12.17% and quality of life scores rising by 15.69%. Qualitative data indicated positive outcomes linked to engagement and family dynamics, though loneliness remained a complex issue.
population_specificity: 50 elderly residents at an old age home in Kodambakkam, Chennai.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of reminiscence therapy based on memories of hard work versus enjoyment in promoting positive reminiscence and reducing depressive symptoms in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that reminiscence therapy based on memories of enjoyment was more effective than therapy based on hard work in promoting positive reminiscence, with a small-to-moderate effect size. No significant differences were reported for depressive symptoms or life satisfaction.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (aged 65+, 3 men and 23 women) attending an elder citizens' club and salon.
effective_dosage: Sessions lasted 30-50 minutes each, once a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the intervention contents and efficacy of group reminiscence therapy in non-clinical older adults.
results_summary: The review found positive impacts of reminiscence therapy on mental health and well-being outcomes, including reduced depression, anxiety, and stress, as well as improved life satisfaction, happiness, and general health. However, the literature on efficacy remains limited, requiring further research.
population_specificity: Non-clinical older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of group reminiscence therapy on the mental well-being of older adults and identify associations with sociodemographic factors.
results_summary: The study found that 76.7% of participants in the experimental group showed significant improvement in mental health after reminiscence therapy, compared to high baseline distress levels in both groups.
population_specificity: Older adults in elderly care facilities in urban north Tamil Nadu, with a mix of urban (experimental group) and rural (control group) backgrounds.
study_duration: 4 weeks (administered from the 2nd to the 5th week)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of Reminiscence Therapy-involved care (RTIC) on cognition, anxiety, depression, and satisfaction in elderly acute coronary syndrome (ACS) patients post-percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
results_summary: RTIC improved cognitive function (higher MMSE scores, lower cognitive impairment rates) and reduced depression (lower HADS-D scores) at 6 months compared to routine care, with no significant impact on anxiety. Patient satisfaction was also higher in the RTIC group at 3 and 6 months.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with ACS who underwent PCI (n=152, aged not specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved a 6-month RTIC program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of group Reminiscence Therapy on depression, anxiety, and self-esteem in community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in depression, anxiety, self-esteem, and the comprehensibility dimension of the sense of coherence scale, with depression showing the largest effect size.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (average age 74.7 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Reminiscence Therapy (RT) in improving cognitive decline and provide evidence for its implementation in dementia care.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that RT significantly improves both immediate and long-term cognitive decline, with no significant differences in efficacy between subgroups. These results support RT as a reliable non-pharmacological treatment for enhancing cognitive function.
population_specificity: People with dementia (2,650 participants across 24 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Group Reminiscence Therapy assisted by Memory Specificity Training (GRT-mest) on depressive symptoms, autobiographical memory, and rumination in older adults, as well as the mediating role of autobiographical memory.
results_summary: GRT-mest significantly improved depressive symptoms, autobiographical memory, and rumination compared to control groups, with effects lasting up to 3 months. Autobiographical memory improvement had a short-term indirect effect on alleviating depressive symptoms immediately post-intervention.
population_specificity: Older adults in nursing homes
study_duration: Assessments were conducted at baseline, immediately post-intervention, and at 1-month and 3-month follow-ups (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a digital app (Recuerdame) to assist occupational therapists in planning, organizing, and documenting reminiscence therapy for older adults with dementia.
results_summary: The app was well-received by occupational therapists, who found it easy to use and believed it would save time, enrich therapy sessions, and improve effectiveness. The usability was rated as excellent, and qualitative feedback highlighted its acceptability and areas for improvement.
population_specificity: Older adults with dementia and their occupational therapists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of reminiscence therapy in reducing anxiety and depression and improving quality of life in adult cancer patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that reminiscence therapy significantly reduced anxiety and depression scores and improved quality of life in cancer patients, with statistically significant results (p < 0.001).
population_specificity: Adult cancer patients during treatment, rehabilitation, and end-of-life periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of individual occupation-based reminiscence therapy delivered at home versus in a dementia care center on cognitive function, depression, and instrumental activities of daily living in older adults with mild dementia.
results_summary: Both therapy groups showed significant improvements in cognitive function, but only the home-based group showed a reduction in depression. The home-based group also demonstrated greater improvements in cognitive function and depression compared to the center-based group.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with mild dementia (n=26).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a reminiscence therapy-involved program (RTIP) on anxiety, depression, and quality of life in cancer patients.
results_summary: RTIP significantly reduced anxiety and depression scores and rates while improving overall quality of life in cancer patients, with particularly notable benefits in digestive system cancer patients. The results were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Cancer patients (1,963 participants across 16 RCTs, including digestive system cancer patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the most effective medium (e.g., old photos, music, movies) for delivering reminiscence therapy to improve cognitive function and reduce negative moods in older adult stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a planned network meta-analysis to compare the efficacy of different reminiscence therapy media, but results are not yet available as this is a protocol for future research.
population_specificity: Older adult patients who had a stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of group music reminiscence therapy (RT) in improving cognition, behavioral and psychological symptoms (BPSD), and quality of life (QoL) in people thriving with dementia (PTD).
results_summary: The study found that group music RT may be useful for symptomatic management in PTD, with Level C recommendation for cognition and Level B recommendations for BPSD and QoL (ineffective). However, heterogeneous study designs and outcome measures limit clinical translation.
population_specificity: People thriving with dementia (PTD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the design characteristics of VR-RT and evaluate its effects on user experience, cognitive outcomes, and psychological well-being in older adults.
results_summary: VR-RT was found to improve anxiety, depression, and cognitive outcomes in older adults, with high user enjoyment and no significant side effects like cybersickness. Most studies were high quality, but more randomized controlled trials are needed to confirm effectiveness and optimal treatment dosage.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of Reminiscence Therapy-engaged care (RTEC) on alleviating anxiety, depression, and improving quality of life in elderly postoperative cervical cancer patients.
results_summary: RTEC reduced anxiety and depression scores and improved quality of life but did not enhance cognitive function in elderly postoperative cervical cancer patients with anxiety or depression.
population_specificity: Elderly postoperative cervical cancer patients with anxiety or depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of reminiscence therapy on cognitive and emotional well-being in institutionalized older patients with dementia.
results_summary: The study found positive correlations between alpha and beta waves, suggesting enhanced relaxation and cognitive engagement, but improvements in Hasegawa Dementia Scale-Revised scores were not statistically significant, indicating variability in therapeutic effectiveness.
population_specificity: Institutionalized older patients with dementia at the Long-Term Care Health Facility for the Elderly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of individual reminiscence therapy on cognitive level, quality of life, and depressive symptoms in older adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that reminiscence therapy significantly improved cognitive levels, quality of life (mental and physical health sub-dimensions), and reduced depressive symptoms in older adults with type 2 diabetes compared to the control group. No significant differences were observed in pre-test scores, but post-test results showed statistically significant improvements.
population_specificity: Older adults with type 2 diabetes (58 participants, 29 intervention, 29 control).
effective_dosage: Two sessions per week (each 40-45 minutes) for 5 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of group reminiscence therapy on cognitive function, subjective well-being, and behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) in older adults with moderate to severe dementia.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in cognitive function (HDS-R scores) but reported significant improvements in subjective well-being (PGC Morale Scale) and reduced BPSD (NPI-NH scores). These results suggest group reminiscence therapy is effective for improving well-being and reducing BPSD in dementia patients.
population_specificity: Older adults with moderate to severe dementia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Reminiscence Therapy on anxiety, depression, spiritual well-being, and quality of life in elderly patients with unresectable, metastatic gastrointestinal cancer.
results_summary: Reminiscence Therapy significantly reduced anxiety and depression scores, improved spiritual well-being, and enhanced quality of life over a 6-month period compared to usual care alone. The benefits were more pronounced in patients with baseline anxiety or depression.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with unresectable, metastatic gastrointestinal cancer (n=222).

study_goal: To examine the effect of individualized reminiscence therapy on global distress, physical and psychological symptoms, life satisfaction, and self-transcendence levels in palliative care patients.
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy showed significant reductions in general distress and psychological symptoms within the intervention and placebo groups, but no significant differences compared to the control group. It significantly improved life satisfaction and self-transcendence in the intervention group compared to others.
population_specificity: Palliative care patients without cognitive impairment and able to communicate in western Turkey.
effective_dosage: Eight sessions, every other day, each approximately 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to replicate the effects of cognitive-reminiscence therapy (CRT) on psychological resources and mental well-being and extend findings to anticipated pleasure.
results_summary: CRT significantly improved anticipated pleasure, psychological resources (self-esteem, self-efficacy, optimism), and reduced depressive symptoms compared to the control group, with effects sustained at follow-up. Partial replication was observed for meaning in life and negative automatic thinking.
population_specificity: 75 participants (60% female, mean age 43.7 ± 16.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how verbal Reminiscence Therapy (VRT) and Music-assisted Reminiscence Therapy (MRT) are viewed and used in practice by those working with older adults.
results_summary: VRT and MRT were frequently used to address varied needs of older adults, leading to reported positive outcomes such as better care practices, improved mood, and enhanced social connections. MRT was employed as a compensatory strategy when traditional VRT was not feasible.
population_specificity: Older adults in Australia, with 110 participants who worked or volunteered with this demographic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of spiritual reminiscence therapy (SRT) on depression and hope among older adults in Shahroud, Iran.
results_summary: The study found that SRT significantly reduced depression and increased hope in older adults, with statistically significant differences between the intervention and control groups. The results suggest SRT is beneficial for alleviating despair and fostering hope in this population.
population_specificity: Older adults living in Shahroud, northeast of Iran.
effective_dosage: Six weekly sessions, each lasting 60 to 90 minutes.

study_goal: To determine the effect of virtual reminiscence therapy on depression and anxiety in patients with gastric cancer undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy significantly reduced depression and anxiety scores compared to the control group, with improvements maintained at 3 months post-intervention. The therapy shifted anxiety levels from mild-moderate to normal range.
population_specificity: Patients with gastric cancer undergoing chemotherapy (N=152).
effective_dosage: Not specified (delivered over the phone in addition to routine care).
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of virtual reality reminiscence versus traditional reminiscence therapy on cognitive function and psychological well-being in older adults.
results_summary: Both VR reminiscence and traditional RT significantly improved cognitive function and psychological well-being compared to pre-intervention and the control group, with statistically significant differences (P <0.05).
population_specificity: Older adults in assisted living facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of resourcefulness-based instrumental reminiscence therapy (RBIRT) on psychological adjustment, learned resourcefulness, self-efficacy, social support, and quality of life in nursing home residents.
results_summary: Participants receiving RBIRT showed significant improvements in psychological adjustment, learned resourcefulness, self-efficacy, social support, and mental health-related quality of life compared to the control group, with sustained effects at 1- and 3-month follow-ups.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents in Fujian, China (n=120, aged older adults).
effective_dosage: Not specified (6-week intervention involving Reminiscence Interview, Emotional Venting, Reconstruction Strategies, Planning for the Future, and Strengthening Support).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Reminiscence Therapy on cognition, agitation, and quality of life in older adults with dementia receiving long-term care in Turkey.
results_summary: The study found that Reminiscence Therapy significantly improved cognition, reduced agitation, and enhanced quality of life in older adults with dementia, with effects persisting up to 3 months post-intervention. The results were statistically significant (P < 0.001) and favored the RT group over the control group.
population_specificity: Older adults with dementia residing in a long-term care center in Turkey (n=54, 27 in RT group and 27 in control group).
study_duration: Intervention effects were measured at baseline (T0), 1 week (T1), 1 month (T2), and 3 months (T3) post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of Reminiscence Therapy on autobiographical memory networks (AMN) in older adults using fMRI and assess its psychological effects.
results_summary: Reminiscence Therapy reduced anxiety and activated key areas of the AMN, including the medial prefrontal cortex, precuneus, occipital cortex, and hippocampus, supporting its role in memory network modulation.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (n=11) without baseline depression or memory impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the differential improvement in quality of life for older adults in different aging conditions (healthy aging, mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease) and from different countries (Spain, Mexico) using a positive reminiscence therapy program (REMPOS).
results_summary: REMPOS therapy significantly improved the recall of specific positive memories across countries and aging types, except for the Spanish MCI group. Life satisfaction improved in the Mexican Alzheimer's and MCI groups but not in the Spanish sample.
population_specificity: 144 older adults (65+ years) from nursing and retirement homes in Spain and Mexico, including those with healthy aging, mild cognitive impairment, and Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the effectiveness of a reminiscence therapy-based hybrid board game, Journey of Memories, in reducing anxiety and loneliness among older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the board game intervention significantly reduced anxiety (STAI-S and STAI-T scores) and loneliness (UCLA scores) in the experimental group, with high usability and user experience ratings.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 61-75 (38 participants, 20 in the experimental group, 18 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Three sessions of the board game intervention, with a 5-day interval between each session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of life review and reminiscence therapy in enhancing quality of life and life satisfaction among older adults and to identify effective intervention variables.
results_summary: The study found that reminiscence therapy significantly improved quality of life and life satisfaction in older adults, with individual sessions and six to eight intervention sessions showing the most impact.
population_specificity: Older adults (2353 participants across 32 studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus on form and number of sessions: individual sessions and six to eight sessions were most effective).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of different trapping agents (ammonium sulfate, sulfobutylether-β-cyclodextrin, and sucrose octasulfate) on the remote loading efficiency and antitumor performance of irinotecan-loaded liposomes.
results_summary: TEA-SOS liposomal CPT-11 demonstrated slower drug release, prolonged circulation time, and significantly improved antitumor efficiency compared to other formulations. The study highlights the role of trapping agents in controlling drug aggregation/crystallization and loading efficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (preclinical investigation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review studies assessing the association between sodium intake and blood pressure in children with various clinical conditions.
results_summary: The study found a positive association between sodium intake and blood pressure in most studies, with meta-analysis showing significant increases in systolic and diastolic BP per additional gram of sodium intake daily in children with elevated BP without identifiable cause.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (0-18 years) with clinical conditions, including elevated BP, familial hypertension, cardiovascular risk factors, chronic renal insufficiency, urolithiasis, and premature infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the expression of cellular retinol-binding protein-1 (CRBP1) in lesional skin of alopecia areata patients compared to controls to understand its role in the disease's pathogenesis.
results_summary: CRBP1 expression was significantly higher in alopecia areata lesions compared to normal skin, with a strong positive correlation between CRBP1 levels and the percentage of hair loss (SALT score).
population_specificity: 30 alopecia areata patients and 10 healthy controls matched by age and sex.

study_goal: To demonstrate bioequivalence between the maleate salt-based commercial glasdegib tablet and the clinical di-HCl salt-based formulation, and to assess the effects of a high-fat meal and PPI on glasdegib pharmacokinetics.
results_summary: The maleate salt-based glasdegib was bioequivalent to the di-HCl formulation under fasted conditions. A high-fat meal or concurrent PPI treatment had minimal, clinically insignificant effects on glasdegib exposure.
population_specificity: 24 healthy subjects (subset of 12 for meal/PPI evaluation)
interactions: High-fat, high-calorie meal and proton-pump inhibitor (rabeprazole) had minimal effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the angiographic efficacy, clinical safety, and effectiveness of the Restore paclitaxel-coated balloon (using a SAFEPAX shellac-ammonium salt excipient) compared to SeQuent Please DCB for treating coronary in-stent restenosis in Chinese patients.
results_summary: The Restore DCB was noninferior to SeQuent Please DCB for 9-month in-segment late loss (0.38 ± 0.50 mm vs. 0.35 ± 0.47 mm) and had similar 1-year target lesion failure rates (13.3% vs. 12.6%).
population_specificity: Chinese patients with first occurrence of drug-eluting stent in-stent restenosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of blood pressure variability (BPV) and early morning BP surge (EMBS) on cardiovascular and cerebrovascular risks, with a focus on ethnic differences, particularly in salt sensitivity and hypertension management.
results_summary: The study found that exaggerated EMBS and BPV are linked to increased cardiovascular and cerebrovascular risks, with ethnic differences (e.g., higher salt sensitivity in Asians) necessitating tailored BP management strategies. Long-acting antihypertensives like amlodipine and telmisartan were more effective in controlling EMBS than valsartan.
population_specificity: Western and Asian populations, with specific emphasis on higher salt sensitivity and hypertension prevalence in Asians.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist (MRA) alone or combined with an AT-1 receptor blocker (ARB) affects the aldosterone/renin ratio (ARR) during screening for primary aldosteronism (PA).
results_summary: The study will assess changes in ARR after 1-month treatment with MRA alone and combined with ARB, aiming to establish if these treatments can be administered during PA screening without altering ARR. The study is powered to detect a clinically significant 20% change in ARR.
population_specificity: Consecutive patients with an unambiguous diagnosis of primary aldosteronism (PA) undergoing washout from confounding treatments and subtyped by AVS.
effective_dosage: Canrenone (50-100 mg orally) for 1 month, followed by olmesartan (10 or 20 mg orally) added for another month.
study_duration: 2 months (1 month for each treatment phase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the renal mechanisms linking excessive fructose intake to salt-sensitive hypertension.
results_summary: The study suggests that excessive fructose intake may induce salt-sensitive hypertension, primarily through renal mechanisms such as (pro)renin receptor-dependent activation of the intrarenal renin-angiotensin system and increased nephron sodium retention.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of mechanisms, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the importance of hemodynamic assessment and fluid therapy, including balanced salt solutions, in patients with liver failure.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the use of crystalloids and balanced salt solutions to mitigate risks like hyperchloremic acidosis in liver failure patients, with albumin resuscitation showing additional benefits beyond volume expansion.
population_specificity: Patients with acute liver failure (ALF) or acute on chronic liver failure (mainly cirrhosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the causes, diagnosis, and treatment options for the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuresis (SIAD) in hospitalized children.
results_summary: The study identified SIAD as a common cause of hyponatremia in hospitalized children, with diagnostic markers including hypouricemia and elevated fractional excretion of urate. Treatment options included fluid restriction, saline solutions, sodium supplements, loop diuretics, urea, and vasopressin receptor antagonists.
population_specificity: Hospitalized children with SIAD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate strategies for managing diuretic resistance in heart failure patients, including the role of salt restriction.
results_summary: The study found that salt restriction is one of several strategies to aid decongestion in heart failure patients with impaired diuretic response, alongside other methods like higher diuretic doses or sequential nephron blockade. However, the abstract notes a lack of high-quality clinical data to guide treatment choices.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients with diuretic resistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of apremilast in treating moderate-to-severe alopecia areata (AA).
results_summary: The study found that apremilast showed potential in treating AA, with the primary endpoint being a 50% reduction in SALT score, but specific efficacy results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 30 moderate-to-severe AA patients (≥50% scalp involvement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize Bartter and Gitelman syndromes, conditions involving renal salt-wasting, and explore their clinical presentations, genetic causes, and treatment options.
results_summary: The study found that these syndromes present with hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, varying from severe antenatal disease to asymptomatic cases. Treatment may involve electrolyte replenishment and targeting specific biochemical pathways, but genotypic-phenotypic correlations are still under investigation.
population_specificity: Patients with Bartter and Gitelman syndromes (renal salt-wasting conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary salt reduction lowers blood pressure and cardiovascular risk in individuals with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) receiving dialysis.
results_summary: Dietary salt reduction was associated with an 8.4 mmHg reduction in systolic blood pressure (95% CI 4.8-12.0) in dialysis patients. The study included 12 selected reports, with four RCTs meeting inclusion criteria.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) receiving hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis.
effective_dosage: Reduction in salt intake of at least 1 g/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of altered salt intake on serum cardiotrophin-1 (CT-1) levels and its relationship with blood pressure in humans.
results_summary: The study found that high-salt intake significantly increased serum CT-1 levels, particularly in salt-sensitive individuals, and these changes were positively correlated with blood pressure and urinary sodium-to-potassium ratios. Low-salt intake reduced CT-1 levels.
population_specificity: 44 adults (18-65 years) from a rural community in northern China.
effective_dosage: Low-salt diet (3.0 g/day NaCl), high-salt diet (18.0 g/day NaCl).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review randomized clinical trials to assess the effects of reduced dietary salt intake on outcomes in adults with heart failure.
results_summary: The review found limited and inconclusive evidence regarding the benefits of salt restriction for heart failure patients, with mixed results on functional class improvement and insufficient data on primary outcomes like mortality and adverse events.
population_specificity: Adult inpatients or outpatients with heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence-based best practices for intraoperative fluid management, focusing on minimizing salt and water uptake through intravenous crystalloid infusions.
results_summary: The study emphasizes the importance of maintaining intravascular volume and minimizing salt and water uptake during surgery, recommending discontinuation of intravenous fluids postoperatively once oral intake is tolerated.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing surgery within an enhanced recovery after surgery pathway.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate immune-mediated mechanisms by which salt influences blood pressure elevation and target organ damage in hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that immune cells and inflammatory mediators modulate hypertension by affecting the kidney, vasculature, skin, and nervous system, with specific roles for monocytes, neutrophils, dendritic cells, and T cells. Regulatory T cells (Tregs) were noted to protect against hypertension and kidney injury.
population_specificity: Rodent models (mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if home blood pressure monitoring (HBPM) combined with health education (including salt reduction advice) could reduce blood pressure and improve medication adherence in hypertensive adults.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant reduction in blood pressure or improvement in medication adherence from HBPM and education (including salt reduction advice). The intervention did not outperform usual care.
population_specificity: Adults with hypertension (213 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing guidelines and treatments for managing hypertension before pregnancy, including dietary sodium intake recommendations.
results_summary: The study highlights that recent guidelines encourage women with chronic hypertension to reduce or substitute dietary sodium intake before pregnancy to lower risks of pregnancy-related hypertensive disorders. However, the abstract does not provide specific data on salt's direct effects or outcomes.
population_specificity: Women with chronic hypertension planning for pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to challenge the historical theory of salt sensitivity (renal dysfunction) and explore the contemporary "vasodysfunction theory," which attributes salt-induced hypertension to abnormal vascular resistance responses rather than sodium retention.
results_summary: The study highlights that salt sensitivity may stem from abnormal vascular resistance responses to increased salt intake, not greater renal retention, and suggests dietary strategies for reducing salt-induced hypertension risk without necessarily reducing salt consumption.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of salt-sensitive vs. salt-resistant subjects)

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to elucidate the molecular mechanisms and genetic disorders related to jaundice and cholestasis, not specifically studying Salt.
results_summary: The study did not investigate Salt; it focused on genetic liver diseases, bile metabolism, and treatments for cholestatic disorders.
population_specificity: Patients with genetic liver diseases, particularly those manifesting jaundice and cholestasis in early childhood.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the use of α-glucans in oral rehydration salt solutions (ORS) for diarrhoea therapy and explore strategies for further development.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the importance of rehydration using ORS, noting the inclusion of glucose for sodium absorption despite its high osmotic pressure. It also discusses the emerging use of α-glucans in ORS formulations as a newer therapeutic approach.
population_specificity: Not specified (general diarrhoea therapy, likely broad population).

study_goal: The study does not address Salt; it focuses on drug-induced liver injury (DILI), herbal-induced liver injury, and herbal and dietary supplement (HDS)-induced liver injury.
results_summary: The study does not report any findings related to Salt.
population_specificity: Not applicable (Salt not studied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess adherence to salt-restriction as part of non-pharmacological therapies among hypertensive patients and its association with blood pressure control.
results_summary: The study found that overall adherence to lifestyle modifications, including salt-restriction, was low (6.0%). There was a significant association between adherence to non-pharmacological measures (including salt-restriction) and reductions in systolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Ambulatory hypertensive patients from two tertiary healthcare institutions in Sokoto, Northwestern Nigeria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the precipitating factors of heart failure decompensation, focusing on poor adherence to treatment, including inadequate salt intake.
results_summary: Poor adherence to treatment, including irregular medication use and inadequate salt and fluid intake, was the main factor for heart failure decompensation, accounting for 55% of cases. Patients with irregular medication use had a 22% higher risk of hospitalization due to poor adherence.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 years with decompensated heart failure (functional class III/IV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of β-Hydroxy-β-Methylbutyrate (HMB) in stimulating muscle protein synthesis, minimizing muscle breakdown, and enhancing recovery, particularly comparing free acid and calcium-salt formulations.
results_summary: The study suggests HMB may help maintain muscle mass and reduce inflammation during intense training, with the free acid form potentially more effective than the calcium-salt form, though evidence is not conclusive due to methodological flaws.
population_specificity: Trained and untrained individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical effects of dialysate sodium concentration (DNa) on sodium balance, blood pressure, and related outcomes in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Low DNa reduced interdialytic weight gain and blood pressure but increased hypotensive episodes and muscle cramps. Sodium profiling reduced hypotension but risked hypernatremia, with the sodium gradient being more predictive of outcomes than DNa alone.
population_specificity: End-stage renal disease patients on hemodialysis.
effective_dosage: DNa levels varied, including ramping up from above 140 mEq/L to nonphysiological levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between ABO blood groups and platelet function, particularly in response to antiplatelet therapies involving aspirin and P2Y12 inhibitors like 2-MeSAMP.
results_summary: Blood type A was associated with higher platelet reactivity and a greater risk of myocardial infarction, while blood type O showed higher arachidonic acid-induced platelet aggregation but lower risk of poor response to clopidogrel and 2-MeSAMP. The study suggests alternative antiplatelet therapies may be needed for poor responders with these blood types.
population_specificity: 206 patients who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and received dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel.
effective_dosage: 10 and 30 µmol/l of aspirin or 30 and 100 µmol/l of 2-MeSAMP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative use of chloride-restricted intravenous fluids reduces the incidence and severity of acute kidney injury (AKI) in patients undergoing off-pump coronary artery bypass graft (OPCABG) surgery.
results_summary: The study found that chloride-restricted IV fluids significantly reduced the incidence of Stage-I AKI (4.6% in Group B vs. 9.2% in Group A, P < 0.05). Chloride-liberal IV fluids were associated with hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing OPCABG surgery (n=600, divided into two groups of 300 each).
effective_dosage: Not specified (various IV fluids used, including hydroxyethyl starch in 0.9% normal saline, Ringer's lactate, balanced colloid solution, and balanced salt crystalloid solution).

study_goal: To assess the efficacy of oral rehydration salts in children with neurally mediated syncope of different hemodynamic types.
results_summary: Oral rehydration salts increased the cumulative response rate compared to health education alone, particularly in children with vasodepressor vasovagal syncope. No significant differences were found in short-term effects among different hemodynamic types.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-18 years diagnosed with neurally mediated syncope (vasovagal syncope or postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome).
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 6 to 25 months (mean 14.82 ± 6.13 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the formulation of GDC-0810, specifically its salt form (N-methyl-D-glucamine salt), for Phase III clinical trials by reducing surfactant content while maintaining pharmacokinetic performance.
results_summary: The study identified a Phase III formulation with reduced sodium lauryl sulfate (SLS) content that achieved comparable pharmacokinetic exposure to the Phase I/II formulation when administered with a low-fat meal. The 'Make and Test in Parallel' approach enabled efficient optimization.
population_specificity: Patients with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of speech and language therapy (SALT) for aphasia rehabilitation, focusing on optimal dose, intensity, timing, and distribution of treatment.
results_summary: The study found that sufficient treatment dose is necessary for clinical gains in aphasia rehabilitation, with e-therapies being a promising method to achieve this. It also highlighted the need to understand interactions between aphasia, cognitive deficits, and secondary effects like low mood for personalized treatment.
population_specificity: Individuals with aphasia, potentially with associated cognitive deficits or secondary effects like low mood and social isolation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if early changes in mineralocorticoid receptor (MR)-related biomarkers, including salt taste intensity (STI) and salt pleasantness (SP), could predict treatment outcomes in major depression.
results_summary: The study found that STI increased and SP decreased with treatment, but these changes were not clearly related to treatment outcome. Early reductions in cortisol and aldosterone, along with increased slow wave sleep (SWS), were linked to better clinical outcomes after 6 weeks.
population_specificity: 24 patients with unipolar major depression (out of 30 initially enrolled).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing and new literature on sodium and water homeostasis, focusing on the effects of high-salt and low-water intake and their clinical significance.
results_summary: The study found that sodium and water dysregulation significantly impacts kidney and vascular health, linking maladaptation to high-salt and low-water intake to hypertension and chronic kidney disease. It also highlighted the role of arginine vasopressin and non-osmotic sodium storage.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ketoprofen lysine salt (KLS) versus paracetamol/acetaminophen (P) on pain perception during rapid maxillary expansion (RME).
results_summary: KLS was more effective than P in reducing pain during the fourth, fifth, and sixth days of RME activation. Patients using KLS for the first three days reported significantly lower pain throughout the entire active phase.
population_specificity: Prepubertal children (mean age 8.6 years) with posterior transverse interarch discrepancy.
effective_dosage: 40 mg KLS once a day for the first 3 days of activation.
study_duration: First 3 days of activation, with pain assessed over 6 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of high dietary salt intake in the development and exacerbation of autoimmune diseases.
results_summary: High sodium intake was associated with increased risk of autoimmune diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis and multiple sclerosis, by promoting pro-inflammatory T-cell phenotypes. Animal models supported these findings, but clinical epidemiological studies showed mixed results.
population_specificity: Genetically susceptible individuals and animal models (e.g., MRL/lpr mice, collagen-induced arthritis models).

study_goal: The study aimed to determine the prevalence of the lukS/F-PV gene (encoding PVL toxin) in S. aureus strains from skin/soft tissue infections, burn wounds, and nasal colonizers, and to assess antimicrobial susceptibility.
results_summary: The study isolated 127 S. aureus strains, with 32.3% being MRSA and 67.7% MSSA. The lukS/F-PV gene was found in 21 MRSA and 31 MSSA strains, with high antimicrobial resistance observed in MRSA and PVL-positive MSSA.
population_specificity: Out-patients with skin/soft tissue infections, burn wounds, or nasal colonization in Lahore, Pakistan.
study_duration: Data collection occurred from July 2014 to June 2015.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the phenotypic heterogeneity in 11β-hydroxylase deficiency and its association with CYP11B1 mutations, focusing on clinical features like hypertension and salt wasting.
results_summary: The study found that CYP11B1 mutations led to highly variable phenotypes, ranging from mild to severe virilization, early-onset hypertension, or salt wasting, with significant differences in clinical outcomes among siblings.
population_specificity: Two families with siblings presenting with 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, including individuals with genital ambiguity, precocious puberty, hypertension, and salt wasting.
study_duration: Varied follow-up periods, including a 5-year follow-up for one patient.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance and limitations of predictive formulas for serum sodium (SNa) correction in treating profound hyponatremia, based on Edelman's linear regression model.
results_summary: The study illustrated the utility and constraints of existing formulas for predicting SNa response during treatment, using data from a critically ill patient with severe hyponatremia (SNa 101 mEq/L). It highlighted the narrow therapeutic window for correction and the importance of balancing rapid correction with the risk of osmotic demyelination.
population_specificity: Critically ill patient with profound hyponatremia (SNa 101 mEq/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the prevalence of masked hypertension in children with risk factors for arterial hypertension, including increased salt intake.
results_summary: The study found that 9.1% of children with risk factors had masked hypertension, with increased salt intake being one of the most common personal risk factors. Obesity and family history were also prevalent among those with masked hypertension.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-11 years with normal blood pressure and at least one risk factor for arterial hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether interventions like salt/fluid restriction could counteract overnight fluid shift and reduce sleep apnea severity.
results_summary: The study suggests that interventions targeting fluid overload, including salt restriction, attenuate nocturnal fluid shift and reduce sleep apnea severity, with greater reductions in fluid shift correlating with greater improvements in apnea severity.
population_specificity: Individuals with sleep apnea, particularly those with conditions associated with fluid overload.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed therapeutic approaches for IgA nephropathy, including the role of salt restriction in disease management.
results_summary: The abstract mentions salt restriction as a general measure to slow disease progression in IgA nephropathy, but no specific results regarding salt's effects are provided.
population_specificity: Patients with IgA nephropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the challenges in diagnosing and treating hyponatremia in oncology settings.
results_summary: The study found that identifying the cause of hyponatremia in oncology settings can be challenging, and misdiagnosis may delay appropriate therapy.
population_specificity: Cancer patients and those undergoing cancer therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of salt-inducible kinases (SIKs) in gene expression regulation and their therapeutic potential in response to cAMP signaling.
results_summary: The study highlights how cAMP signaling influences SIK function in gut myeloid cells, bone, liver, and skin, leading to advances in GPCR signal transduction and therapeutic applications of SIK inhibitors.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on cellular and molecular mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to interpret recent advances in human gustatory pathways, focusing on the laterality of gustatory responses, particularly in relation to salt perception and handedness.
results_summary: The study found a predominant left ipsilateral pathway for salt perception with the right preferred hand, with evidence of ipsilateral projection from the left primary gustatory cortex to the orbitofrontal cortex. It also suggested that gustatory responses depend on taste quality and supported the Labelled-Line Model theory of peripheral taste quality encoding.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human gustatory pathways, with mention of handedness as a factor)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether spot urine samples could accurately detect changes in population sodium and potassium excretion compared to 24-hour urine samples.
results_summary: The study found that published equations using spot urine samples failed to detect sodium excretion differences measured by 24-hour urine samples. However, a method combining spot urine electrolyte concentrations with a standard urine volume showed promise for estimating sodium and potassium excretion differences between groups.
population_specificity: 3270 Chinese individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential additive effects of a low-protein diet (LPD) and RAAS inhibitors on slowing chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression, with a focus on salt intake.
results_summary: The study found that combining an LPD with RAAS inhibitors reduced proteinuria and glomerulosclerosis in animal CKD models, but high-quality human trials are lacking. Salt intake was discussed as a factor in CKD progression, but specific effects were not detailed.
population_specificity: Animal models with CKD and general clinical studies (human data not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of salt reduction as part of a multifactorial approach to managing metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: The study suggests limiting salt consumption as part of lifestyle modifications to reduce MetS risk factors, but it does not provide specific data on salt's direct effects or outcomes.
